Chapter 3 Git Basics 3.1 Getting a Git repositery There are two ways for obtaining a Git repository: - Transform an existing local directory without version control into a Git repositor - Clone an existing Git repositery from somewhere else 3.1.1 Initializig a Repository in an Existing Directory First, you have to go to the project directory # work directory initial_repo = "D:/git_test/Git_Book/" setwd(initial_repo) # Repository directory name dir_name = "MyRepo" new_repo = paste(initial_repo,"MyRepo", sep = "/") # verify if the repo file exist and remove it if it exists if(dir.exists("D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo") == TRUE){ unlink("D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo", recursive = TRUE) } # we create a project directory dir.create("MyRepo") ## Warning in dir.create("MyRepo"): 'MyRepo' existe déjà # Then we go to that projetc directory setwd(new_repo) shell("dir") # initialize a git repository shell("git init") This creates a new subdirectory named .git that contains all necessary repository files (a git repository skeleton). Now we can start version-conrolling files and do initial commits. setwd(new_repo) # First we have to specify our identity shell('git config --global user.name "Saif Shabou"') shell('git config --global user.email "saif.shabou@gmail.com"') print(getwd()) ## [1] "D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo" # then we create a new file and commit this action nb = sample(1:1000, 1, replace=TRUE) filename = paste("file_",nb,".csv", sep = "") file.create(filename) ## [1] TRUE cmd_add = paste("git add", filename, sep = " ") shell(cmd_add) shell('git commit -m "adding new file"', intern = TRUE) ## [1] "[master (root-commit) d9cbc47] adding new file" ## [2] " 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)" ## [3] " create mode 100644 file_269.csv" 3.1.2 Cloning an existing git project When we want to get a copy of an existing Git repositery we can use git clone shell("git clone https://github.com/S-AI-F/Remote-sensing-image-analysis MyClone") ## Warning in shell("git clone https://github.com/S-AI-F/Remote-sensing-image- ## analysis MyClone"): 'git clone https://github.com/S-AI-F/Remote-sensing-image- ## analysis MyClone' execution failed with error code 128 3.2 Recording Changes to the repositery

Chapter 4 GitHub 4.1 Adding an existing project to GitHub 1- Create a new repository on GitHub. To avoid arrors, do not initialize the new repository with README, license, or gitingore files. You can add these files after your project has been pushed to GitHub 2- Open Git Bash 3- Chan the current working directory to your local project setwd(dir = "D:/git_test/Git_Book/_book") 4- Initialize the local directory as a Git repository shell("git init") 5- Ad the files in your new local repositor. This stages them for the first commit shell("git add .") ## Adds the files in the local repository and stages them for commit. To unstage a file, use 'git reset HEAD YOUR-FILE'. 6- Commit the files that you have staged in your local repository shell('git commit -m "My First commit"',intern = TRUE) ## [1] "[master bce0307] My First commit" ## [2] " 6 files changed, 12 insertions(+), 6 deletions(-)" # Commits the tracked changes and prepares them to be pushed to a remote repository. To remove this commit and modify the file, use 'git reset --soft HEAD~1' and commit and add the file again. 7- At the top of your GitHub repository’s Quick setup page, copy the remote repository URL 8- In the Command prompt, add the URL for the remote repository where your local repository will be pushed # sets the new remote shell('git remote add origin https://github.com/S-AI-F/GitBook.git') ## Warning in shell("git remote add origin https://github.com/S-AI-F/GitBook.git"): ## 'git remote add origin https://github.com/S-AI-F/GitBook.git' execution failed ## with error code 128 # Verifies the new remote URL shell('git remote -v', intern = TRUE) ## [1] "origin\thttps://github.com/S-AI-F/GitBook.git (fetch)" ## [2] "origin\thttps://github.com/S-AI-F/GitBook.git (push)" 9 - Push the changes in your local repository to GitHub # Pushes the changes in your local repository up to the remote repository you specified as the origin shell('git push origin master') 4.2 Getting changes from a remote repository These commands are very useful when interacting with a remote repository. clone and fetch donload remote code from a repository’s remote URL to your local compter. merge is used to merge different people’s work tohether with yours, and pull is a combination of fetch and merge. 4.2.1 Cloning a repository # Clones a repository to your computer shell('git clone https://github.com/USERNAME/REPOSITORY.git') 4.2.2 Fetching changes from a remote repository Use git fetch to retrieve new work done by other people. Fetching from a repository grabs all the new remote-tracking branches and tgs without merging those changes into your own branches. # Fetches updates made to a remote repository shell('git fetch remotename') 4.2.3 Merging changes into your local branch Meging combines your local changes with changes made by others. # Merges updates made online with your local work shell('git merge remotename/branchname') 4.2.4 Pulling changes from a remote repository git pull is a convenient shortcut for completing both git fetch and git merge in the same command # Grabs online updates and merges them with your local work shell('git merge remotename branchname') Because pull performs a merge on the retrieved changes, you should ensure that your local work is committed before running the pull command. If you run into a merge conflict you cannot resolve, or if you decide to quit the merge, you can use git merge --abort to take the branch back to where it was before you pulled.
